result.execSummary:
The defendant Timothy P. King was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI (4th), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.
Must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and a driver safety plan.  You must also comply with any recommendations.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of probation.    Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of probation.
Obtain and maintain full time employment acceptable to his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Maintain absolute sobriety.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, or by any other means with Kimberly King and Anita Whiteeagle, or their residences.

Not to own or be responsible for any domestic animals.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

supervisions.notes: A civil judgment is ordered for all unpaid court ordered financial obligations.

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Osborne.  Parties have the revocation packet.  State recommended:  Follow DOC recommendation.   1 year jail in 15CM203.  All other sentences running concurrent.  Defense recommended:  366 days credit in 15CM203.  Asking to adopt DOC recommendation.  Defendant exercised his right to allocution.  

Court ordered:  

15CM203  -2 counts.  Count 1.  1 year jail.  Count 4.  6 months jail. 

16CM177 - 1 count.  90 days jail.

17CM22 - 1 count.  6 months jail.

17CM79 -2 counts.  Count 3. 6 months.  Count 4. 6 months jail.

17CM108 -2 counts.  Count 1.  6 months jail.  Count 2.  90 days jail.  

All to be served concurrent.  Credit for 275 days.  

Judgment for unpaid court ordered financial obligations.
Stephanie Osborne

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Satorius.  In 17CM22 defendant plead no contest to Count 8.  In 17CM79 defendant plead no contest to count 4.  In 17CM79 defendant plead no contest to count 3.  In 17CM108 defendant plead no contest to count 2 and count 1.  In 15CM203 defendant plead no contest to count 1 and count 4.  In 16CM177 defendant plead no contest to count count 2.  Amended complaint filed in 15CM203.  Waive reading of the amended complaint.  Victim notification complied with.   Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  He understood. Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the pleas.   Court confirmed the prior OWI convictions with Attorney Satorius.  Court found that the defendant freely and voluntarily entered his pleas and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the pleas.  Found guilty of each charge he plead to.  All other criminal counts and civil cases tracking are dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Joint recommendation for:  OWI 4th.  3 years probation.  6 months jail.  900.00 fine, plus costs. $2122.00 total.  24 mo DL rev & IID.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan.  Allowed to deduct.  Remaining cases.  2 years probation.  6 months conditional jail in 17CM79 Count 1.  Consecutive to OWI jail sentence.  DNA sample.  No contact K.K. and A.W., unless they agree and agent approves.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Maintain absolute sobriety.  AODA and recommended treatment.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Not own or be responsible for any domestic animals.  

Court ordered sentence withheld:   in 15CM203 OWI 4th,  3 years probation.  6 months conditional jail.  $900.00 fine, plus costs. $2122.00 total.  24 months driver's license revocation & IID requirement.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan.    Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats..  Remaining cases: 2 years concurrent probation.  6 months conditional jail in 17CM79 on count 1.  Consecutive to OWI jail sentence.  No contact K. K. and A.W. or their residence.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Maintain absolute sobriety.  AODA and recommended treatment.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Not own or be responsible for any domestic animals.  CC.    Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.  Obtain and maintain full time employment, agent approves.  140 days credit on 15CM203.  Apply bond to OWI fine.

records.addlTxt: The defendant appeared by video from the Jackson County Jail.

Covers 15CM203, 15CM234, 16CM119, 16CM177, 16CM190, 17CM5, 17CM22, 17CM23, 17CM79, 17CM108.  Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.   Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.
ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.    The defendant appeared by video from the Jackson County jail.  Attorney Satorius appeared in court.  Set for a plea in December.
